title: 2022 United States Senate elections
added: On June 26, 2020, the United States House of Representatives voted 232â€“180 to grant statehood to the District of Columbia.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Cochrane |first=Emily |date=June 26, 2020 |title=House Approves D.C. Statehood in Historic Vote |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/us/politics/dc-statehood-house-vote.html |url-status=live |archive-url= |archive-date= |website=The New York Times |access-date=October 5, 2020}}</ref> Depending on the results of the [[2020 United States elections|2020 elections]], it is possible that the [[117th United States Congress|117th congress]] (2021-2023) will grant statehood to the District of Columbia. This would add two seats to the Senate, both of which would probably be filled in special elections during the 2022 election cycle. The addition of these two seats, extremely likely to be won by Democrats,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fisher |first=Marc |date=February 22, 2016 |title=It's hard enough to be a Republican in deep-blue D.C. Try being a Trump voter. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/its-hard-enough-to-be-a-republican-in-deep-blue-dc-try-being-a-trump-voter/2016/02/22/d8f18b96-d4f2-11e5-9823-02b905009f99_story.html |url-status=live |archive-url= |archive-date= |website=The Washington Post |access-date=October 5, 2020}}</ref> would have a significant effect on the nationwide partisan battle for control of the Senate.

In addition, a [[2020 Puerto Rican status referendum|referendum on the status of Puerto Rico]] is set to be held on November 3, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Puerto Rico Statehood Referendum (2020)|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Puerto_Rico_Statehood_Referendum_(2020)|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 12, 2020|website=Ballotpedia}}</ref> Depending on its result and the results of the 2020 elections, it is plausible that the 117th congress will also grant statehood to Puerto Rico. The 2020 [[Party platform|platforms]] of both the Democratic Party<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=July 31, 2020|title=2020 Democratic Party Platform|url=https://www.demconvention.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/2020-07-31-Democratic-Party-Platform-For-Distribution.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 12, 2020|website=}}</ref> and the Republican Party<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Republican Platform 2016|url=https://prod-cdn-static.gop.com/docs/Resolution_Platform_2020.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 12, 2020|website=GOP}}</ref> (identical to the 2016 Republican Party platform) express support for Puerto Rico's right to determine the future of its status. Both seats would likely be filled in special election during the 2022 election cycle. Unlike the District of Columbia, the  partisan lean of Puerto Rico is somewhat unclear. While Latino Americans of Puerto Rican descent tend to vote for Democrats, many argue that Puerto Rico's heavy Catholic population<ref>{{Cite web|last=Krogstad|first=Jens Manuel|date=March 29, 2017|title=Key findings about Puerto Rico|url=https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2017/03/29/key-findings-about-puerto-rico/#:~:text=A%20majority%20(56%25)%20of,identified%20as%20born%2Dagain%20Christians.|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 12, 2020|website=Pew Research Center}}</ref> will result in Puerto Rico agreeing with the Republican Party on many social issues like abortion, religion in schools, and same-sex marriage.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Reingold|first=Olivia|date=September 9, 2020|title=Is Puerto Rico the Next Senate Battleground?|url=https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2020/09/09/puerto-rico-statehood-politics-democrats-republicans-senate-409191|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 12, 2020|website=Politico}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States Senate elections
deleted: On November 3rd, 2020, the state if Alaska approved ranked-choice voting. This will be the first senate election conducted under this system.
